question: What is the general process for translating a page?
answer: To translate a page, one first writes the content in the original language. Second, the page is marked for translation. Then, a ''human'' translates the page using organizational tools provided by the wiki extension [https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Extension:Translate Translate]. Finally, a second human reviews the translation.

question: Which wiki extension is used for page translation?
answer: The wiki extension [https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Extension:Translate Translate] provides organizational tools for translation.

question: What happens if a page has not yet been translated?
answer: If a page has not yet been translated, users can see the page in the original language.

question: What happens if a translation has not yet been reviewed?
answer: If a translation has not yet been reviewed, users can see the non-reviewed translation.

question: What does marking a page for translation accomplish?
answer: Marking a page for translation will trigger an analysis of the content of the wiki page. The page content will be split by the extension into so-called translation units.

question: What are translation units?
answer: Translation units can be a title, a paragraph, an image, etc.

question: What are the benefits of using translation units?
answer: These small units can then be translated one by one, ensuring that a modification to a page does not trigger the translation of the whole page. This also allows tracking of what percentage of a page is translated, or outdated.

question: What are the steps to mark a new page for translation?
answer: #Ensure that the wiki code to be translated is enclosed within <translate> </translate> tags. #Ensure that the tag <languages /> appear at the very top of the page. This will show a box#Go in “View” mode, and then click on the “Mark this page for translation” #Review the translation units. ##Try to ensure that no wiki code (tables, tags, etc.) gets translated. This can be done by breaking the page in multiple <translate> </translate> sections.#In the “Priority languages” section, write either “fr” or “en” as the priority language, that is, the language into which it needs to be translated.#Click on “Mark this version for translation”

question: Which tag must appear at the very top of a page to be translated?
answer: The tag <languages /> must appear at the very top of the page.

question: How can one prevent wiki code from being translated when marking a page?
answer: Try to ensure that no wiki code (tables, tags, etc.) gets translated. This can be done by breaking the page in multiple <translate> </translate> sections.

question: What are the accepted priority languages for translation?
answer: In the “Priority languages” section, write either “fr” or “en” as the priority language, that is, the language into which it needs to be translated.

question: When should a page be marked for translation, ideally?
answer: First, try to mark a page for translation only once it is stable.

question: Which automatically generated tags should not be changed when modifying a translated page?
answer: Make sure you do NOT change the tags of the form <!--T:3-->. Those are automatically generated.

question: What text indicates that a page has un-marked changes since its last translation marking?
answer: You should see the text “This page has changes since it was last marked for translation.” at the top of the page.
